abstract: The year 2000 compliance issue is challenging and will continue to test many organizations even beyond the first day of the new millennium. This presentation will address the subject of insurance coverage for organizations and how it impacts quality, not only in view of the year 2000 concern, but also beyond that issue. Insurance companies are becoming increasingly concerned about all aspects of the way those who are insured by them conduct business from quality to liability exposure and potential litigation.

title: The Value of Information Technology Services
abstract:
The worth of I.T. services can be judged only in the context of the financial performance of the entire enterprise. The first part of the presentation will show comparisons between Lockheed-Martin and look-alike firms,such as Boeing, TRW and others. The analysis will show that the central focus of I.T. services in L-M should concentrate on reducing the Cost of Goods, which include the costs of Purchases and Administration expenses.

Since the primary value of I.T. services can be found in improving organizational effectiveness, the potential gains from further integration with the supply value-chain will be highlighted as the most likely top priority objective for L-M.

The discussion about I.T. services efficiency gains will dwell on the measurement of Information Productivity as the entire enterprise and how I.T. can identify the most rewarding investment opportunities.

The presentation will conclude with observations about benchmarking I.T. spending, especially in comparison with prices quoted by outsourcers. Emphasis will be placed on the re-allocation of I.T. spending from ongoing operations and maintenance expenses to funds that need to become available for making innovative investments.

title: Measuring and Evaluating the Productivity of Corporate Information Management
abstract:
The line items reported by U.S. industrial corporations as Sales, General, Administrative and Research & Development offer the most reliable public estimates of what it costs to manage and coordinate a business internally as well as to communicate with suppliers and customers. This expense, conventionally identified as "overhead," is as good a representation of the costs of information management as is available. It includes not only the payroll for the people engaged in information tasks but also expenses for advertising, promotion, consultants and information technology.

An examination of how the costs of information management relate to all other costs of doing business offer valuable insights for a Chief Information Executive who aspires to be more than just a Chief Computer Executive. Mr. Strassmann will describe how over the last ten years the U.S. industrial corporations:

  • Lowered the costs of information management required to deliver goods and services to customers
  • Increased per employee information management costs faster than employee compensation
  • Lowered information management costs in support of revenues;
  • Lowered the ratio of information management costs to operating profits;
  • Lowered the ratio of information management costs to net assets in place
  • Information Productivity has improved since 1991.
While these changes were taking place the U.S. industrial corporations also showed the following characteristics:
  • Ninety-two percent of firms incurred higher expenses for information management than for the costs of ownership of their net capital assets. This makes the utility of asset-based productivity ratios (such as ROA, ROI or ROE) questionable as a measure of performance;
  • Only fifty-eight percent of firms delivered a positive economic value-added (EVA). This makes accounting profits questionable as a measure of operating results
Mr. Strassmann will show how Economic Value-Added (EVA) and Information Productivity ratios should be used in assessing a firm's effectiveness in use of information resources. Emphasis will be placed on specific planning and financial budgeting methods.

title: Risk Management: The Need for a Shared View Among the         I.T. and the Operating Executives
abstract: Fifty-six percent of the US workforce is employed         in information occupations and about eighty percent of         this workforce depends on computers to function effectively.         In the face of this accelerating dependency, IT projects often         fail from the inability to properly plan for risk and to clearly         communicate those risks, and their associated benefits, to the         executive level. Every executive must now become fluent in assessing         and dealing with the potential risks from the failure of their         information initiatives since failure penalties often exceed the         cost of information technologies. Risk management, as a means         for allocating scarce resources, has become at least as important         as the purely technological issues which up to now have been the         primary focus of dialogues between general managers and computer experts.

title: Smartsourcing for Innovation
abstract:
The old forms of outsourcing, e.g. taking over a customer's costly, obsolete and labor intensive information systems can be characterized as "junkyard" operations.

The rapidly emerging new demands for systems innovations will rely on Internet-based architectures that keep "client" and local "server" assets to the barest minimum and will offer centralized utilities consisting largely of data repositories and application processing "farms".

Successful outsourcing arrangements will become the means for an organization to achieve cost reductions and competitive improvements through innovation, not through custodianship of technologically obsolete assets.

Junkyard outsourcing will not be profitable because it will be stuck with the risks and costs for unwinding obsolete services and declining number of transactions.

Profits (and value-priced operations) will be made in those smartsourcing contracts where the outsourcers who can offer large savings and superior new competitive capabilities. This requires shift to vastly more efficient architectures that are not fat client/fat server centric, but thin client/wide band/central utility focused.

In due course the competition between the junkyard and the smartsourcing architectures will be resolved in favor of network centric (the network is the computer) solutions.

Strassmann will emphasize that if an outsourcing strategy concentrates on short-term cost reductions for existing systems assets, everybody will be a loser. The customers for outsourcing will lock themselves into long term commitments which will increasingly become economic liabilities.

Therefore, operating cost reductions as the primary criteria for entering into smartsourcing relationships, will increasingly lead everyone down a destructive path. Viewing smartsourcing as an engine for building "knowledge capital" through innovation then becomes by far the most reliable metric for judging the merits of smartsourcing initiatives.

Strassmann's lecture will show how one can assess what is the dollar value of Knowledge Capital and explain how to estimate the worth of"intellectual capital."

The lecture will discuss the reasons for the many inconsistenciesin the current valuations of information resources.A critique of present budgeting and planning practiceswill describe how excessive concentration on budgetingknowledge acquisition as a current expense and not as along-term investment leads to waste of this valuable asset.

Knowledge Capital metrics offer practical insights howto evaluate and justify investments in a firm'sinformation infrastructure, in improved life-cycle costingof software and in designing reliable databases. title: Planning and Budgeting Practices to Assure the Realization of IT Benefits
abstract:
Throughout his career Paul Strassmann has challenged thinking on the relation between information technology and the profitability of companies. At the Congress his thought-provoking presentation will address the topic of:
"Even superior execution cannot compensate for an inferior choice what to do. Whether IT investments contribute to increased economic value-added is largely determined when plans set forth goals and objectives and when budgets allocate funds, missions and schedules for implementation. Planning and budgeting are the only time when top management can make sure that IT is "aligned" with the goals of a firm. During planning and budgeting the risk destiny of IT is pre-set in that it sets in place the risk. expectations, performance measures, schedules and major technology choices. After all of these decisions are largely locked in, the IT organization is not left with too many choices except how to execute the plans the best way they know how.

It will be the central theme of Mr Strassmann's presentation that IT executives do not devote sufficient time to the planning and budgeting process because they are always rushed to proceed with installation and delivery of systems. Such haste is in most cases the single greatest source of all IT fatalities."

The Economics of Information Security, Extortion, Ransom and Arson
abstract: Information security is expensive--counted in trillions of dollars worldwide.                              For decision-makers weighing the need for infosecurity against its cost, the real                              challenge is determining how much  money to spend and when to deploy it to                              effectively balance expenses and risks. In this authoritative session you will                              discover how  the time-tested principles of risk management, as developed by                              the insurance industry, offer the best economic cost/benefit models for                              allocating funds for information security. You will find out why, in the case of                              individual organizations,  insurance practices that dictate the adoption of  codes,                              standards, independent inspection, risk-pooling and reinsurance can also apply                              to information warfare situations. You will find out why policy makers should                              examine actuarial practices and formal risk engineering as cost-containment                              measures. You will also review examples of extortion, ransom, and arson                              insurance policies that will illustrate practices that can be used when handling                              information warfare exposures.

Mr. Strassmann will suggest that estimating the worth of a firm's "Knowledge  Capital" should be the preferable method for arriving at the size of  vulnerable information-related assets.Ê He will show how to make such  valuation calculations and how to apply them in explaining expenditures for  information protection.Ê The presentation will include illustrative examples  of key metrics, such as the valuation of "Knowledge Capital" per employee  and the ratio of Financial to Knowledge Assets.

venue: European Forum on Advanced Strategies and Technology
title: Where are the Profits from E-Commerce?
The Economic Structure of E-Commerce
abstract:
Business-to-business e-commerce is the next great opportunity for expanding the influence of IT people. Terms such as "value-chain streamlining" and "eliminating work-flow processes" have crept into the vocabulary of IT executives, as corporate Boards push their IT shops to proceed with yet nother round of huge investments.

Whenever predictions of huge savings call for large expenditures, IT executives may boost their standing by offering verifiable evidence as to where the profits may end up.

Mr. Strassmann has examined the cost structure of more than 10,000 industrial suppliers. Since suppliers of finished goods, in turn, depend on other suppliers, he was able to construct a financial model of the costs of the entire supply pipeline, usually involving up to four major layers of intermediaries. It offers an explanation of where the money is spent. At each layer of supply a firm adds to its costs information expenses for sales, marketing, administration, research and development, and IT. These costs, averaging 16% are included in the manufacturer's sales price, thus taking out a big chunk out of the manufacturer's value added. When each manufacturers' information costs are added up they may amount to anywhere from 25% to 45% of a product’s wholesale price.

Thus cost reduction in information management across the entire supply pipeline becomes the largest opportunity for boosting profits. Mr. Strassmann will show examples how the analysis total information management across all of the layers of supply value chain is necessary before justifying an e-commerce project. The greatest benefits will be realized only by those who will have the market power to extract value chain savings and then retain them as profits.

title: Assessment of Information Productivity of Corporations
The Economics and Futures of Business to Business E-Commerce
abstract:
Business-to-business and business-to-consumer E-commerce systems are the next great opportunities for making profitable IT investments.Ê As IT spending flows into transforming existing software into Internet-based E-commerce services it becomes imperative to figure out who will benefit and how much profit will be realized from these technologies.Ê Whenever predictions of huge savings call for multi-million funding it may enhance the career of an IT executive to show where the gains can be found after E-commerce schemes become operational.

Strassmann has examined the financial records of more than 10,000 industrial suppliers and has analyzed their cost structure.Ê Since suppliers of finished goods also depend on other suppliers, he was able to construct a financial model of the entire multi-stage supply pipeline. This model offers an explanation of where the money is presently spent and what costs become displaceable by E-commerce.Ê He will also show how the rising economic power of global business-to-business purchasing consortia is likely to end up dominating the pricing of E-commerce transactions when the elimination of weak competitors takes place.

The presentation will explain how an IT executive should analyze E-commerce opportunities. It will demonstrate that, on the average, 35% of revenue now embedded in the entire supply pipeline becomes eligible for displacement by means of E-commerce. The entire presentation will focus on the total information content, as a share of the final price of a purchased item. A special examination will also focus on the potential retail savings in business-to-consumer sales.

A partial preview of the topics that will be covered in this presentation can be found here.

title: Documents, Knowledge Capital and Information Systems
abstract:
The study of the written word offers one of the most insightful ways of understanding all human progress.Ê All wealth is the result of accumulation of capital, first in the form of land, then in the form of financial assets and now in the form of knowledge.Ê In the historical evolution of the human species the changes in the delivery of recorded information - in the form of documents - has always marked the beginning of a new phase in social advancement.

Mr. Strassmann will illustrate the results of his work on the dominant role of Knowledge Capital in the global economy.Ê Based on his work as the originator and organizer of the Xerox Exhibition on the History of the Written Word he will show how technological changes have always resulted in the shifts in economic power in favor of those who could control the creation and distribution of recorded knowledge.

With the explosive growth of the global Web we are now witnessing an unprecedented disruption in existing relationships.Ê Mr. Strassmann will discuss what are the consequences of the Web now containing an estimated 550 billion documents.Ê Everyone can now enter the document publishing business as the systems costs of creation and distribution approach zero.Ê The industrial-age emphasis on reducing the costs of making documents will now be displaced by systems that will enhance that capacity of individuals to comprehend the contents.

title: What are your Employees Worth?
abstract:
All great ideas must ultimately be subject to the test of economic viability.Ê Much of the prevailing rhetoric about "intellectual capital", "knowledge economy" and "employees-as-our-most-important-asset" appears to be more attractive when preached from the lectern as compared with the difficulties in defending spending proposals during budget reviews.

Paul Strassmann's approach to Knowledge Capital applies the disciplines of financial analysis to calculate, in ways that are verifiable and reproducible, the worth of corporate assets which at present are aggregated as non-quantifiable attributes of Quality, Corporate Culture, Customer Franchise, Organizational Capabilities and the widely fluctuating differences between stock market and accounting valuations of corporations.

This keynote will cover the following topics:

  • 1. The Economic Structure of U.S. corporations
  • 2. Problems with Accounting and Stock Market Valuations Ê
  • 3. How to quantify a firm's Knowledge Capital (with illustrative examples) Ê
  • 4. How to attribute Knowledge Capital to Employees and how to evaluate employee compensation if they are evaluated as an "asset".Ê Each of these topics will be illustrated by examples of calculations for named firms.

title: Measures of I.T. Leadership
abstract:
One way of defining what is the elusive concept of "leadership" is by showing how one would evaluate it. There are are a number of popular methods for ranking leadership excellence. These may lead to unexpected results and Strassmann will show why this is so.

To define leadership in measurable terms Strassmann will base his observations on research that has shown that making strategic choices and competitive assessments account for most of the financial results. A distinction will be made between "management" which is concerned with operational effectiveness and "leadership" which involves making tradeoffs between risky and often conflicting choices. The presentation will include an illustrative case and demonstrate what an I.T. executive ought to do in order to align investments in I.T. projects with corporate strategies and goals.

client: C4E - Centro de Eficiência, Eficácia e Estratégia Empresarial
title: Information Management Governance and Productivity Assessment
abstract:
• Session 1
    Information Management Governance:

    Strassmann uses the word "governance," but he really wants to talk about "organizational politics." He distinguishes between information management and information technology. This lecture will center on a view that the optimal organization is a federation. In a federation, power is balanced between a central unit and a number of constituent units. Strassmann uses the constitutional model to develop a seven-layer information constitution. The top layer is global and includes all functions that deal with the outside; the bottom layer is personal and includes all data that people want to keep private.

  • Session 2
    Information Productivity:

    The primary objective of this presentation is to demonstrate that conventional measures of corporate productivity, such as Return on Assets (ROA) or Return on Investment (ROI) overlook the dominance of information management expenditures in the determination of financial results. Strassmann will outline a 15-step process for analyzing the effectiveness of managerial, administrative, marketing and all other information-handling personnel. In this context information technologies are seen as enablers of human productivity and not as investments that explain productivity gains.

  • Information Technology:

    This session will explain how one can answer the question whether information technology expenditures are inadequate or excessive. Techniques for making comparisons with spending by competitors (e.g. competitive benchmarking) will be emphasized and illustrated.

  • Knowledge Capital:

  • Information management constitutes both a primary cost and the most valuable asset of corporations in the new economy. However, traditional accounting practices offer no consistent method for incorporating a measure of this vital ingredient. Strassmann has formulated a set of metrics to surmount this shortcoming and to permit executives, information managers, and investors to make informed decisions and project into the future likely consequences of past performance. Knowledge Capital provides an operational means for comparing the economic health of corporations from routinely reported financial data.

  • Session 3
    The Economics and the Future of Business-to-Business E-Commerce:
    Strassmann has examined the financial records of more than 10,000 industrial suppliers and has analyzed their cost structure. Since suppliers of finished goods also depend on other suppliers, he was able to construct a financial model of the entire multi-stage supply pipeline. He will also show how the rising economic power of global business-to-business purchasing consortia is likely to end up dominating the pricing of E-commerce transactions when the elimination of weak competitors takes place. The presentation will explain how an IT executive should analyze E-commerce opportunities.

The Role of the CIO and Information Superiority
abstract:
"The Role of the CIO" fits particularly well since Strassmann has recently revisited the research done by the PIMS organization on what determines profitability.

Strassmann's recent studies of corporations with recognized reputation for IT sophistication (e.g. Motorola, Chrysler/Daimler, Xerox and EDS) show that the role of IT may come to play only if it does NOT perform, e.g. when it fails. Otherwise, IT should be seen only as an arms race where all competitors have the identical computer technologies and therefore cannot have a sustainable competitive advantage.

If that is so, the role of the CIO emerges as being largely "political/governance", with technology pushed back either to a CTO or, increasingly to a services provider and outsourcing purchases.

This lecture is unconventional and is contrary to much of what the usual CIO glorification magazines promote.

title: The Whys and the Hows of Ballistic Missile Defenses
abstract:
What constitutes the threats to national security, what are the ballistic weapons already in possession of our potential attackers, how ballistic weapons operate and what are the engineering problems for our defenses are topics that will be receiving much attention in the years to come.

Strassmann, the former Director of Defense Information, will discuss "Defending the U.S. The Why and How of Ballistic Missile Defense." In a profusely illustrated lecture he will show pictures of missile launches and missile intercepts. The BMD budget, the inventory of missiles in hostile hands and the political aspects of existing treaties will be also discussed. The presentation will explain why the U.S. is, at present, defenseless against ballistic missile attacks and is likely to remain that way for years to come.

title: Transforming I.T. Costs into Profits
abstract:
The contribution of I.T. to profitability of firms is indirect, often quite subtle and always unmeasurable at the enterprise level of analysis. To understand this relationship requires a thorough understanding of the determinants of corporate profitability.

Perhaps the only empiric study that illuminates this question is the research that has been conducted for over 25 years by the Strategic Planning Institute (the PIMS research) and its follow-on research organizations. Strassmann will describe the basis for such analysis of corporate profitability and illustrate how the PIMS methodology would guide the planning and budgeting of I.T. investments.

title: The Politics of Information Management
abstract:
Based on his 35 years of experience as the computer chief for major corporations
Strassmann is in a good position to lead the discussion about the  "Political"
(e.g. "Governance") aspects of corporate information management.
According to Strassmann's 1993 book on this subject "...information management
is the continuation of organizational politics by other means."  Politics, not
economics, usually shapes choices of technologies.  Politics largely
determines whether computer projects will succeed or fail.  Politics is by far 
the most frequent cause of a firings of systems executives.
The solution to political infighting is the institution of rules of governance that offer guidelines how to partition the conflicting forces.  Governance
offers the means for achieving a balance between centralization and decentralization of business functions.  The techniques for resolving opposing tendencies cannot be learned from books about information technology.  Reading
up about constitutional history, or attending this workshop, will most
likely be useful in learning what to do.

title: Software Defects: Gateways to Cyberterrorism
abstract:
Though walls, sentries, gates and locks
make a fortress more secure a faulty
foundation and poor design will
always make it penetrable.

Mr. Strassmann will describe why and
how existing software engineering and 
network architectures are inherently 
defective.  The blame for this
situation can be placed on vendors 
who deliver software that is bloated to meet
primarily marketing needs.  The fault also
rests with application designers
who deliver software of
such complexity that it is humanly infeasible
to protect it.

The solution to this situation can be found
in the adoption of systems architectures of
much greater simplicity.  This requires the placement
of most of the software codes in computer utilities
where much higher security standards
can be implemented and enforced.
Since such changes would 
compromise the privacy of individuals
Strassmann is advocating the separation
of personal from corporate computing
software management practices.

title: Software Defects: Gateways to Cyber-Terrorism
abstract:
Software Defects: Gateways  to Cyberterrorism

Though walls, sentries, gates and locks
make a fortress more secure a faulty
foundation and poor design will
always make it penetrable.

Mr. Strassmann will describe why and
how existing software engineering and 
network architectures are inherently 
defective.  The blame for this
situation can be placed on vendors 
who deliver software that is bloated to meet
primarily marketing needs.  The fault also
rests with application designers
who deliver software of
such complexity that it is humanly infeasible
to protect it.

The solution to this situation can be found
in the adoption of systems architectures of
much greater simplicity.  This requires the placement
of most of the software codes in computer utilities
where much higher security standards
can be implemented and enforced.
Since such changes would 
compromise the privacy of individuals
Strassmann is advocating the separation
of personal from corporate computing
software management practices.

site: Hotel Le Plaza, 118-126 Boulevard Adolphe Max, 1000 Brussels
title: The Changing Role of the CIOs
abstract:
The keynote will address the rapidly changing roles of the
CIO as principal vendors (Microsoft, IBM, Sun,
H-P, Cisco and Oracle) are changing their business model
from selling (or licensing) technology to offering
completely integrated application services.

The Strassmann model scenario shows that at present the customer
spends internally about 73% of total IT costs, with
the balance going to vendors.  The most likely
scenario is that within 10-15 years the customer
shares of IT spending will decline to less than
40%, with vendor supplied computer services taking
over most of the remaining IT costs.  This will result in drastic cuts in 
corporate IT staffs.

This news may not be welcome by some CIOs
- nevertheless the evidence is
now overwhelming that the era of large
scale growth of corporate IT staffs is
over as more efficient methods of
software and communication management
practices become available.  If the Strassmann scenario
is reasonably close to what the future
will bring about, then the 
staffing and organization of the 
corporate IT function will result in 
a far-reaching re-examination of 
missions an responsibilities.

This de-emphasis on managing technology
will finally allow the CIO to become
what has always been the mission:
the rationalization of Information Management
instead of over-emphasis on keeping hardware
and software functioning effectively.

The coming changes will enlarge the
roles of the CIO, not diminish them!

title: Justifying I.T. Spending in an Era of Scarce Funding
abstract:
Mr. Strassmann will demonstrate how new analytic techniques could be applied in justifying IT investments.

It is probable that during their tenure each IT executive from the electric and gas utility industry will be confronted with the challenge to prove that they contribute to superior productivity results. Mr. Strassmann has analyzed the Information Productivity® of over 100 US electric and gas utility firms. He found that a number of firms could be vulnerable to outsourcing their IT operations because of substandard performance. The purpose of his presentation will be to explain how IT executives should measure and evaluate their productivity in terms that are relevant to financial executives as well to any regulatory inquiries.

title: Measuring the Transaction Productivity of Organizations
abstract:
The Government Performance Results Act of 1993 requires Departments and Agencies to describe the means for verifying and validate measured values. This calls for the application of "Outcome measures" to asssess the results of an activity as compared with its intended purposes.

\n\nStrassmann's remarks will address the question of Agency productivity measurement by focusing on the ratio of cost of goods to the costs of the total value-chain transactions. Examples from General Motors, K-Mart and Wal-Mart will be used to illustrate the application of the proposed measures.

title: Justification of IT Spending
abstract:
In this presentation Strassmann will "play act" the preparation of a presentation to the Executive Committee of a firm that has applied the published industry <IT as % of Revenue Ratio> to suggest a 10% cut in IT spending. The purpose of my talk will be to demonstrate, in a step-wise sequence, how one should approach such a challenge.

The talk will illustrate how the structure of a corporation shapes IT spending and how it determines the TCO of information management. The talk will highlight how one should explain the TCO in comparison with superior as well as inferior competitors.

title: War-gaming Information Terrorist Threats
Justifying IT Spending in an Era of Scarce Funding
abstract:
The objective of this Master Class is to equip an IT executive with techniques and methods how to respond to inquiries about the value of IT.  Contemporary survey results of CEOs, CFOs and CIOs confirm that reviews of IT will be subjected to especially skeptical examinations in the years to come. Session 1 will deal with reviews of business cases for making investments in individual projects.  Such examinations usually take place at the Departmental level.
Session 2 will address how IT affects the viability of individual businesses and will concentrate on the application of Information Productivity measures.  Such examinations are conducted mostly during Operating budget reviews.
Session 3 will examine the strategic impacts of information technologies and how they affect the Knowledge Capital as well as risks in competitive confrontations in the 21st century.  These matters are of concern at the Board of Directors level and arise during major re-examinations of enterprise strategies.

abstract:
Paul Strassmann will be the guest speaker at our March 19 luncheon, where he will share his thoughts on the power politics of the Chief Information Officer (CIO). In his lively speech and the ensuing question/answer period he will demonstrate that a successful CIO must manage information technology as a continuation of bureaucratic power politics. title: The Future of Federal Network Services
10th Annual Federal Observance
Aligning IT Projects for Value
abstract:
Mr. Strassmann will describe three approaches for achieving favorable economic returns from I.T. and how to align I.T. with the goals of an organization.

The first approach addresses the management of technologies; the second deals with the productivity of administrative personnel; the third covers competitive gains.

The talk will concentrate on how information technology proposals ought to be structured to settle conflicts about investment priorities and for getting executive attention focused on potential economic gains.

Large scale investments in industrial machinery lagged until General Motors pioneered the adoption of formal methods of financial analysis and budgetary planning in the early 1920's.

We have just come the end of a 50-year period of euphoric growth in the adoption of computers but without a disciplined approach to the evaluation of prospective payoffs. The pervasive effects of information technology investments make it now necessary to integrate such expenditures with the existing financial disciplines.

Mr. Strassmann is unanimously recognised as the leading worldwide authority in the area of IT investment justification. He will explain what will fail and recommend what will succeed when asking for scarce funding.

title: The #1 CIO Issue:  How to Explain and Justify the I.T. Budget
abstract:
Last year, corporations worldwide spent over $2 trillion on information technology. Half of that was spent by US corporations alone. But did they get their money's worth? How can you really measure white-collar productivity? What are the real causes of success and failure in corporate information management?

\n\nDrawing on his years as the head of information systems at Kraft Foods, Xerox, the US Department of Defense, and NASA, Paul Strassmann is a renowned authority on IT productivity and return on investment - issues that have come to dominate the agenda of many organizations today.

title: Explaining to your CFO why IT <u>does</u> matter
abstract:
The May issue of the Harvard Business Review carried a an article by one of its Editors with the provocative title "IT Does not Matter". The author declared that information technology has become strategically irrelevant. Consequently the article recommended the adoption of the following policies:

A. Cut the IT budgets;
B. Do not invest in information-technology innovations;
C. Invest only after others have succeeded – follow not lead;
D. Delay IT investments because prices are dropping and everything will be less expensive later;
E. Refocus from seeking opportunities to managing vulnerabilities and risks;
F. Disregard vendors’ innovative offerings because they are suspect for seeking added revenues;
G. Delay innovation as the preferred way for cutting IT costs.

Strassmann responded to each of the HBR recommendations in a letter cited in publications such as Fortune and The New York Times. Because the HBR article is likely to be used as guidance in IT budget reviews for 2004 and 2005, Strassmann will discuss how and why the arguments presented in the HBR article have little merit. Strassmann will also offer specific recommendations how CIOs should get ready to demonstrate IT relevance in an era wherein cutbacks in spending for information technologies have become one of the preferred ways how to improve financial performance.

Strassmann has served as CIO since 1961 for General Foods, Kraft, Xerox, the Department of Defense and NASA. He is author of five books and hundreds of articles about the economics of computer investments. For more information consult and biographical information on

title: The Written Word from Cave Drawings to Interstellar Communication
abstract:
Our civilization has been steadily accumulating wealth because we have acquired the capacity to keep adding to the stores of shared knowledge. Though our origins can be traced back for 400,000 years, it was the invention of writing, about 5,000 years ago, that propelled much of the progress in politics, religion, law and technology.

Understanding how the evolution of the written word relates to the progress in human culture is now necessary for comprehending the consequences of the current explosion in global communications.

Mr. Strassmann will accompany his talk with illustrated examples that span 10,000 years of recored communications. This will include cave drawings, precursors of writing, the evolution of the alphabet and how printing as well as electronic transmissions are causing revolutionary changes in organizations. His talk will also use copies of exhibits from the collection of written communications, still on display in the lobby of the Xerox HQ in Stamford. He will also show a print of signals from Project SETI, now searching for communications from outer space, as well as pictures of NASA extra-terrestial probes. An original sheep-skin page from Gutenberg's printing shop will be also on display.

Biography:
When the new Xerox HQ was originally planned in 1977, Strassmann volunteered to assemble a collection of historical examples that would serve as a testimonial to the contributions of xerography towards the advancement of shared knowledge. Although his background is technical (MIT, 1955), he has found that his interest in the history of communication has been helpful in steering the adoption of computers under rapidly changing circumstances.

Since 1961 he has served as Chief Computer executive for General Foods, Kraft, Xerox, Department of Defense and NASA. Strassmann, a New Canaan resident and publisher of books since 1975, is a frequent lecturer on the historical changes brought about by information technologies. His early predictions that the "paperless office" will never happen received global attention from bibliophiles and archivists.

title: Managing Outsourcing: The CIO Challenge for the Next Decade
abstract:
Increasing technical complexity in developing firm-specific applications, rising labor costs for software maintenance and rapid obsolescence of information technology favor the shifting of internal IT costs to externally purchased services.

The 1-to-5 ratio of external to internal IT costs reflecting the 1990's allocation of IT budgets will now transform to a 3-to-1 ratio by the end of 2010.

The increased emphasis on outsourcing will be also illustrated by a number of examples showing that this is not a unique IT trend but a reflection of global competitive trends seeking to improve information productivity by all available means. The consequences on the organization, leadership skills and the management of IT will be far reaching. Mr. Strassmann expects that systems integration, project management and technology migration planning will now emerge as the main challenges that the CIOs will need to master.

The proliferation of application-specific infrastructures, the redundancies in data definitions and the escalating support costs have delivered systems that are not affordable. Mr. Strassmann will show why systems management will be shifting focus from systems development to systems integration.

title: Is Outsourcing Profitable?
abstract:
The history of U.S. industrial firms for the last 20 years can be characterized by an increasing dependency on outsourcing to suppliers, subcontractors or even to customers. This phenomenon has been explained on the assumption that specialists, or lower cost vendors, could deliver contributions to the cost of goods at a discount. Proponents of outsourcing were also relying on information technologies to lower the administrative as well as coordination costs to manage the increased complexity in all transactions. However, despite the logic that would favor outsourcing, little evidence has been produced to support outsourcing as a general industrial policy.

In this lecture Prof. Strassmann will show results of his studies over the last ten years which have demonstrated that outsourcing does not consistently deliver lower costs and increased profitability. This lecture will be illustrated by the record of General Motors who have increased the amounts of outsourcing from 58.8% in 1986 to 75% in 2004 while experiencing a steady degradation in profitability as well as a severe decline in its Knowledge Capital per employee. While the number of General Motors employees was declining, the ratio of transaction costs to value-added was rising which raises the question whether GM's outsourcing of I.T. was effective.

The presence of the perverse effects of outsourcing have been now detected for a large number of U.S. industrial firms. Prof. Strassmann has concluded that the key in making decisions about achieving cost reductions through outsourcing is to also consider the effects on the consequential gains or losses in a firm’s Knowledge Capital. His findings will be supported by financial data from over 500 U.S. industrial firms.

title: How Much is An Employee Worth?
abstract:
Economists have long viewed compensation as an employee’s worth. If an employee receives $100,000 a year, that’s what he’s worth. Prof. Strassmann can demonstrate that such reasoning is a fallacy.

This lecture will present arguments that one must turn to the competitive marketplace to determine the worth of an employee. Chief information officers should understand how to calculate such worth before they move to cut information technology costs. I.T, after all, is a people-to-knowledge value enabler. Because the value of knowledge is often a large multiple of what the accountants report as costs, even small improvements in the ratio of knowledge to costs can result in enormous gains.

Students can learn how to quantify the value of knowledge within an entire company by using a straight-forward formula: subtract a company’s shareholder equity, or financial value, from its market capitalization, or market value, to come up with what is a company’s “knowledge value.”

Strassmann will also explain how such a number can be obtained by applying his trademarked "Knowledge Capital" equation. In the case of the not-for-profit public sector, a comparative calculation can be also performed. Improvements in the value of knowledge can result in value appreciation whereas cost reductions may accomplish that only indirectly.

Only knowledgeable humans — with or without effective I.T. — can deliver productivity, competitive advantages or whatever is necessary to help businesses in thriving. The lecture will include a table of U.S. firms where employees are worth a large multiple of what they are paid.

title: Business Data Transformation
Governance & Alignment In the Era of Business Transformation
The Next IT Tsunami
Measuring and Communicating IT Value
abstract:
SOA discussions have moved from the IT department to the boardroom

Enterpulse is a Platinum sponsor and featured presenter at this year's Executive Forum. The event has been designed to continue the discussion surrounding the fundamental change of SOA. Technology still plays a role in the agenda however, we'll spend most of our time discussing how to unlock the business benefits of SOA: how SOA changes the way the business is organized, how IT investments are prioritized and justified, and how we measure the value of technology spending.

Exclusive networking opportunities for our executive guests, a critical ingredient of the event's success, remain a big part of the agenda, along with the leading minds from our customers and partners. Upon arrival, enjoy an optional golf and evening welcome reception including peer to peer networking. A highlight of the event is the Keynote Speaker, Paul Strassman. Paul Strassmann, one of North America's leading technology minds, is anything but conventional; some call him confrontational. Among his assertions, there is no correlation between IT and a company's profitability. But his experience-including IT leadership at such diverse organizations as the U.S. Department of Defense, General Foods, Xerox, and NASA-makes him uniquely qualified to lead the debate.

Following the opening keynote, as featured speaker, Enterpulse will present and discuss SOA Perspectives: Improving SOA Governance, Advancing IT and Business Alignment and Improving Corporate Performance. In addition to SOA Perspectives, SOA Best Practices are presented with examples from Comcast and Lifeline Systems. Steve Fox, Editor-in-Chief of InfoWorld will lead Panel Discussions such as People and Organizational Change and Prioritizing and Justifying Your SOA Investment.
